author: @alexjeffrey3981
text: he was so close to making a point at the end there about decentering rather than opposing trans politics, but he rambled so hard it was near impossible to listen to. We have the same problem in the UK where we can't unify as a working class because we insist on being divided into pro-trans and anti-trans socialist camps.

replies.author: @agricolaurbanus6209
replies.text:
There is no pro or anti trans socialist camp.
The whole 'trans question' is an astroturfed phenomenon created as part of COINTELPRO.
Body dysmorphia is a serious mental health issue that should be adressed by professionals, and not put in the center of socialist politics to replace the class question. Which identity politics do in general btw.

replies.text:
These are online niche crowds filled with edgelords who only want to argue points they clearly don't understand. That's the audience. 0 normal everyday ppl have or ever will hear about ACP, because yall surround yourself with cringe online dorks who hate you.

replies.author: @Comrade_Alyosha
replies.text:
The people who have the mic in the political sphere of young people are "immature keyboard warriors."
As such, it is important to tackle these issues in their own space and offer an appropriate rebuttal to any misunderstandings and/or slanderous accusations.

replies.author: @ForAJustWorldby2035
replies.text: I agree, Using Social media platforms is definitely the easiest and most effective way to reach new audiences, however this is not a professional or legitimate environment to represent what is supposed to be an actual serious party. Especially with the locker room talk, many people will be immediately alienated.
